text: David were just two days from President
Obama's televised healthcare meeting
help us understand what we might expect
of it first of all are we going to hear
anything we haven't already heard do you
think not in the big picture I mean
we've been debating this for a very long
time the Republicans know the Democrats
ideas the Democrats know the Republicans
ideas this is not a session for them to
really hear new things it is it is much
more political than that and the fact
that it's televised is really the key to
this event so is it really just
political theater or white something of
substance come from it well it really is
political theater but the reason that
something of substance may come from it
is that political theater matters if we
think over the course the debate this
year the the summer was a very bad time
for the White House and Democrats there
were there were these town hall meetings
where people got very upset about health
care and then then Obama came back and
gave this speech to the joint session of
Congress that steered the debate back
the Democrats way and then we have the
election in massachusetts which really
steered it very sharply the Republicans
way and even though the Democrats if
they wanted could still go out and pass
health care bill tomorrow and so
politics matters and and this does have
the potential to be an event that either
kills health reform off or or gives it a
bit of a boost of new life which is
clearly what the White House is hoping
here do you think this really is a
last-ditch effort I mean President Obama
is really stuck his neck out here more
than ever before if we can't get a deal
here fairly shortly does it mean that
health care is dead for the rest of his
term first of all he can't get a deal
here it's not good for them and for the
White House if they can't get a deal
they'll come to something much much
smaller where they'll just look to cover
some some relatively small number of
people in little ways almost Clint onian
ways and then maybe you can imagine them
returning to health reform at some point
but I think if they don't get a big deal
here we are not going to have any kind
of major health reform for years and
years I mean these things tend to come
up every 10 20 years the last one was
Bill Clinton in the early nineties if
they don't get a big deal here I
be surprised if we get a major health
reform anytime soon and now David you're
writing in a story for Wednesday's
newspaper about it's not just the fault
maybe if Republicans and Democrats who
can't agree here but there's has been
extraordinary amounts of lobbying up by
big business by unions how much is is
that lobbying a factor in the failure so
far at least to get a deal it has been a
factor and it's been a factor in both
the the little in the big way in the
little way lobbying affects the way
Congress works and in the big way the
attitude that unions and businesses and
the like take toward health reform
affects people's attitudes toward health
reform and people's attitudes in turn
affect what the government does and so
what we've seen is we've seen a lot of
groups we've seen AARP we've seen labor
unions we've seen business groups
they've really been quite opposed to a
lot of measures that would reduce health
costs growth and you can go down a list
of examples measures that would make it
easier for people to choose their own
insurance as opposed to having their
companies do it for them measures that
would tax high cost insurance plans you
go through all these things people have
looked at this and in fact evidence that
we have suggest these would reduce
health costs would help us in the long
run and and yet all these different
groups have opposed them and part of it
is their narrow interests part of it is
also that change is kind of scary and
you look at it and you think wow that
may be worse than it is now rather than
wow that may be better than it is now
and so there's been a lot of that in
this case
